metadata.title: Title 1 INFECTIVITY OF ATTENUATED POXVIRUS VACCINE VECTORS AND IMMUNOGENICITY OF A 2 RACCOONPOX VECTORED RABIES VACCINE IN THE BRAZILIAN FREE-TAILED BAT 3

body_text.text: Groups of 8 wild-caught T. brasiliensis were separated into two screened flight cages (33"W x 66"D 142

x 84"H) approximately 5 meters apart. Four bats from each group were given 10 9 plaque forming 143 units (PFU) in 100μl of either RCN-luc or MVA-luc by intramuscular (IM) injection, split into two 144 50μl volumes injected into each thigh muscle. The remaining four bats in each group were given 145 the same amount of virus in 70μl sterile saline; using a micropipette with sterile tips, the volume 146 split among the nostrils (10 μl given each nare) and mouth (50 μl) for oronasal (ON) exposure. 147

Bats were monitored for 3 hours post inoculation for signs of adverse effects. Animals were 148 scanned using an IVIS 200 Biophotonic imager (PerkinElmer, Hopkinton, MA, USA) at one-day 149 post infection (dpi) and every-other day thereafter until 2 consecutive images with less than 100 150 radiance units (comparable to background) were observed. Bats were scanned prior to infection 151 and confirmed to have no auto-luminescence beyond background levels. Imaging was conducted 152 at roughly the same time period each day, midway through the bats' active period. On imaging 153 days the bats were separated individually into paper lunch bags, weighed, and injected 154 intraperitoneally (i.p) with d-luciferin (Potassium-Luciferin, Gold Biotechnology, St. Louis, MO 155 63132, dose: 150 mg/kg) at 14 minutes prior to imaging the ON group and 26 minutes prior to 156 imaging the IM group, which were empirically determined to be the time of peak luminescence 157 post substrate exposure on the first day of imaging. All bats were examined for signs of disease or 158 discomfort at the time of substrate injection. For imaging, animals were anesthetized by chamber-159 delivered isoflurane and positioned in the imager in dorsal recumbency with wings extended 160 laterally, where they were maintained on mask-delivered isoflurane. After imaging the anesthesia 161 was ceased, bats were monitored and given thermal support during recovery. After 11 dpi the bats 162 with remaining detectable luminescence were imaged every 3 days until luminescence was below 163 detectable levels. Images were collected and analyzed using Living Image software (Caliper Life 164 Sciences, Alameda, California, USA). A region of interest (ROI) was created which covered the 165 entire body of the bat when analyzing the luminescence data. 166

At 87 dpi, a random group of six bats, all initially exposed to RCN-luc by either the ON (n=4) or IM 167 (n=2) route, was given a booster exposure to the RCN-luc vaccine via the ON route at the same 168 dose. Bats from this group were imaged at 1, 3, and 5 dpi using the same protocol as described 169

above. were also collected at 30 and 60 dpi and used for controls. Serum was collected by making a small 203 lance in the interfemoral vein and collecting up to 200 μl of blood in a capillary tube (Microvette® 204 CB 300 Blood Collection System, Sarstedt AG & Co., Nümbrecht, Germany), which was 205 subsequently centrifuged at 10,000g for 10 min. A micropipette was used to collect the serum 206 from the top of the blood container and transfer it to a separate tube for storage at -80º. 207
Testing was conducted at the CDC Poxvirus and Rabies Branch using standard RFFIT protocols 208

[42], augmented for smaller volumes of serum as previously described [43] . The assay was run in 209 triplicate for each sample, and the results reported represent average titers. Prior to the 60 dpi 210 sample collection, two bats from the RCN-G group were lost from the study due to non-vaccine 211 related mortalities. Table) . All bats infected with 226 luc-expressing poxvirus vectors had detectable expression of luminescence by 1 dpi, and peak 227 levels were observed at 1 and 3 dpi for the IM and ON routes, respectively (Figures 1 and 2 In the group of bats re-exposed to RCN-luc to assess whether prior exposure would affect the 238 infectivity of the viral vectors, no significant difference (P =0.33) was detected in luminescence 239 when compared to initial exposure through 5 dpi (Figure 3) . Table) . As a 255 control, bats vaccinated with luc-expressing virus for the imaging study (N=7) were bled at 0 and 256 60 dpi and assessed by RFFIT as well. By 30 dpi all rabies vaccinated bats (5/5) developed Ab 257 titers greater than 0.2 IU/ml (0.20 -11.46, with a mean of 5.14), while 7/7 bats that received RCN-258 luc had titers ≤ 0.09 IU/ml (S5 table) to RCN, which may be expected due to the highly attenuated nature of MVA. The lack of significant 283 difference in the levels of viral encoded protein (luciferase) production upon re-infection with 284 RCN, as shown in the booster study (Fig. 3) , may be important if bats had been previously exposed 285 to RCN, or if boost inoculations of RCN-vectored vaccine are necessary. While neither vector 286 caused clinical illness, the fact that RCN produced more viral encoded protein (luciferase) over a 287 longer period suggests it is a more immunogenic vector when expressing heterologous antigens. 288
Due to limitations of this study, we were not able to compare the immunogenicity of the vectors 289 directly. 290

The development of significant levels of rabies neutralizing antibodies after ON exposure to demonstrates that the vaccine is highly immunogenic in T. brasiliensis. While previous studies 292 have demonstrated the effectiveness of injectable vaccines in this species[52], our study is the 293 first to demonstrate effective mucosal vaccination. An average anti-rabies G titer of 5.14 IU at 60 294 dpi was detected in bats orally administered RCN-G , which is higher than the levels obtained after 295 vaccination with the VR-G construct in any previous studies, including oral, IM, and scarification 296 routes of exposure (28-30). While these differences may be due to the animal models used, this is 297 additional evidence of the superiority of the RCN vector over vaccinia in bat species. Additionally, 298 the previous studies failed to address the infectivity of vaccinia in the bat host, relying on the lack 299 of clinical disease and development of protective immunity to assess the virus-host interaction. 300
We were unable to assess the duration of immunity past 60 days, but this would be useful 301 information to collect in future studies. 302

Limited oral shedding of the RCN virus was detected in bats by both PCR and culture of live virus 303 up to 9 dpi, but at very low levels. While there was no evidence of shedding of live MVA virus, 304 there was PCR evidence of vector DNA in oral swabs through 7 dpi; detection of live virus may 305 have been limited due to the method used and the necessary lack of lower dilutions resulting from 306 low sample volumes. One of the advantages of in vivo imaging studies is that it is not necessary to 307 sacrifice animals to obtain data, and the bats used in this study went on to be used in a different 308 investigation. Because of this, we were unable to assess organ tissue for evidence of pathology 309 during the infection trials. However, the lack of any apparent morbidity in RCN-treated bats, along 310 with RCN's natural history, record of success in various domestic and non-domestic species, and 311 ability to induce immunity via the oral route, make it a very attractive candidate for use in free-312 ranging bats. 313

The results of our experiments provide proof-of-principle that oral vaccination is possible in free-314 ranging bats. In future work, topical vehicles will be developed that could be used to deliver oral 315 vaccines to the fur coat of bats as they roost or are otherwise congregated. Bats are fastidious 316 animals and spend a large proportion of their time self-grooming [53], which could lead to 317 significant oral exposure to topically applied vaccines. A vaccine that would broadly protect free-318 ranging bats from rabies virus infection may reduce local incidence of rabies in certain bat 319 populations, limiting the amount of spill-over into humans and other species. T. brasiliensis 320 represents a species that roosts in dense colonies and is exposed to significant levels of circulating 321 rabies virus in their population that may result in human exposures [54] . Therefore, a topically 322 delivered rabies vaccine may be directly applicable to this species, but only if a method for mass 323 application (such as a spray) could be developed. Table. Proportional change in body weight for individual bats as compared to weight on day 0. This data was used to compare average proportional change in body weight by group, as shown in S2 Figure] [S4 Table. Luminescence data from each image taken of bats infected with luciferase-expressing constructs. Luminescence (p/s/cm3/str) was calculated from ovoid regions of interest (ROIs) and analyzed with Living Image version 4.2software. This data was used to calculate total luminescence, as seen in Fig.'s 1-3.] [S5 Table. Rabies-neutralizing antibody titers for bats by time point. Titers given in IU/mL as determined by rapid focus fluorescence inhibition test (RFFIT) testing. ]

FIGREF0.text: , supplemented with 2-5% fetal bovine serum (FBS). Viruses were titrated prior to use 116 with plaque dilution assays in 6-well plates.117 2.4. Construction of Recombinant MVA-luc 118 Recombinant MVA-luc viruses were constructed as described elsewhere [39]. Briefly, CEF cells 119 were infected with MVA-GFP at a multiplicity of 0.05 PFU per cell; one hour later the cells were 120 transfected using the FuGENE® reagent protocol (Promega, Fitchburg, WI) with a pI2 transfer 121 plasmid containing 1) DNA flanking segments adjacent to deletion III within the HindIII A 122 fragment of MVA, 2) the Red Fluorescent Protein (RFP) under the control of a p11 promoter, and 123 3) the firefly luciferase gene (luc) under the control of a strong synthetic early/late (SE/L) vaccinia 124 virus promoter upstream (S1 figure). At 48-72 hours post transfection, the cell cultures were put 125 through three freeze-thaw cycles, harvested, sonicated, and centrifuged at 500 x g for 5 minutes at 126 4ºC. The sonicated cell extracts were plated onto fresh BHK-21 cells and overlaid with 0.8% 127 agarose. After 48-72 hours, through the use of specific microscope filters, the recombinant viruses 128 were detected by the presence of the RFP gene, which replaced the GFP gene during homologous 129 recombination. Selected cell/virus samples were sonicated and plated again as described above. 130 After four consecutive rounds of plaque isolation, recombinant MVA-luc virus was confirmed by 131 PCR analysis using OneTaq® Quick-Load® 2X Master Mix with Standard Buffer (New England 132 BioLabs Inc., Ipswich, MA 01938, USA) amplifying the insertion at the Del III flanks using 133 ATGCGGCACCTCTCTTAA as a forward primer and CCAAAGCTTGCACATACATAAGTA as the 134 reverse primer. The virus subsequently amplified in freshly prepared CEF cells. 135 2.5. Bioluminescent Imaging 136 Biophotonic luminescent imaging (BLI) has been successfully used to assess the infectivity, 137 infection course, and tissue tropism of viruses and candidate vaccine vectors [40]. Unlike 138 traditional pathogenicity studies that require euthanasia of animals at different time points, BLI 139 allows study of the course of infection over time in a single host, increasing the information gained 140 while reducing the number of animals required. 141

FIGREF1.text: Assessment of viral shedding 171 During anesthesia for each imaging time-point, oral swabs were collected (CLASSIQSwabs, Copan 172 Flock Technologies, 25125 Brescia, Italy) and placed in a 1.5ml tube containing 200μl DMEM 173 media. Fecal samples were also retrieved when available from the bags in which the individuals 174 were contained during imaging, placed in a 1.5ml tube without media. All samples were quickly 175 stored at -80ºC until testing. Prior to testing, 100μl DMEM media was added to fecal samples, 176 vortexed thoroughly and sonicated four times in a bath sonicator for 15 seconds. DNA was 177 extracted from 40μl of the samples using the Zymo Quick-gDNA™ MiniPrep kit (Zymo Research, 178 Irvine, CA 92614, U.S.A.), and a PCR assay was run to assess for presence of the inoculated virus. 179 PCR was performed with OneTaq® Quick-Load® 2X Master Mix with Standard Buffer (New 180 England BioLabs Inc., Ipswich, MA 01938, USA) and primers targeting the luc insert flanks 181 [supplemental info]. The limit of detection for this PCR protocol was determined to be 0.125 182 picograms of DNA, or 6.8x10 4 copies, as determined by serial dilution of a known quantity of viral 183 DNA. Any samples positive by PCR were then assessed for levels of live virus by determining the 184 median tissue culture infective dose (TCID50). For RCN-luc samples, positive wells were assessed 185 by plaque observation, and the TCID50 was calculated and used to approximate plaque forming 186 units (PFU)/ml by the Spearman & Kärber algorithm [41]. For MVA-luc samples, positive wells 187 were assessed for viral titer by the luciferase marker using steadylite plus™ (PerkinElmer Inc, 188 Waltham, MA 02451). Serial dilutions from 10 -2 to 10 -7 were made, and 100μl from each was used 189 to infect a 96 well plate with BHK-21 cells at ~80% confluency. Due to minimal sample volume 190 left, no smaller dilutions were possible. After 3 days of infection, 100μl of the steadylite reagent 191 was added to each well, mixed by pipetting, and after 15 minutes the plates were scanned in a 192 luminometer (Veritas™ Microplate Luminometer, Turner BioSystems, Inc, Sunnyvale, CA 94085). 193 2.7. RCN-G Immunization 194 An additional group of five T. brasiliensis were housed separately in the same type of caging and 195 given RCN-G via the ON route to assess the immunogenicity of RCN-delivered rabies CVS strain 196 glycoprotein. For this exposure the bats were anesthetized with isoflurane prior to exposure. A 197 dose of 10 8 PFU of viral vaccine was given in 70μl sterile saline, split between 50 μl orally and 10 198 μl in each nare. Bats were monitored through their anesthesia recovery for 3 hours for potential 199 adverse events. Serum samples were obtained prior to vaccination and at 30 and 60 dpi and 200 tested for the presence of anti-rabies neutralizing antibodies by the rapid fluorescence focus 201 inhibition test (RFFIT). Serum samples from bats given RCN-luc (used in the luminescence study) 202

FIGREF2.text: Statistical analysis 213 Analysis of the data was performed using the R-commander software package[44]. Weight change 214 was analyzed with repeated measures ANOVA, where 'weight' is a function of group, route, and 215 time, plus all interactions, using individual bats as the repeated measures. Differences in 216 luminescence were analyzed using a linear mixed-effects model fit by the restricted In vivo imaging studies 221 To assess the infectivity, tissue tropism, and course of infection of RCN and MVA in T. brasiliensis, 222 bats were infected with recombinant virus expressing the firefly luciferase gene (luc). Two routes 223were assessed; the IM route and the ON route, which is most biologically relevant for wildlife 224 vaccination. Throughout the study, no clinical signs of disease, lesions, or significant weight loss 225 were observed after administration of viral vectors (S2Figure, S3

FIGREF3.text: Assessment of Viral Shedding 241 PCR analysis of oral swabs revealed the presence of MVA-luc DNA in 5 out of 8 bats up to 7 dpi (3 242infected IM, 2 infected ON), however no live virus was recovered. RCN-luc DNA was present in 4 243 out of 8 bats up to 9 dpi (2 infected IM, 2 infected ON), with low levels of live virus detected (6.33 244 x10 3 PFU/ml average, with a median of 9.20 PFU/ml in those with detectable virus). Two bats 245 from the RCN-luc group that had live virus detected by oral swabs also had PCR positive fecal 246 samples at 7 and 9 dpi, however no live virus was recoverable from these samples in titration. 247 Viral shedding appears to occur at very low levels independent of route of exposure, and with no 248 evidence of shedding viable MVA. 2493.3. Antibody Responses to RCN-G 250To assess the immunogenicity of RCN, an additional group of bats (n=5) was infected via the ON 251 route with RCN expressing rabies virus surface glycoprotein (RCN-G). Again, there was no 252 evidence of clinical disease in any of the vaccinated bats in this experiment. The rabies virus G is 253 very well characterized and known to induce protective humoral immunity to rabies virus [30, 45, 254 46]. All bats assessed by RFFIT had negligible Ab titers prior to vaccination (S5

FIGREF4.text: . While there is no "protective" level of rabies virus 259 neutralizing antibodies (RVNA), there is a positive correlation between RVNA titers and the level 260 of protection after virus challenge[22, 47-50]. Titers between 0.association between bats and zoonotic diseases, there is currently no significant effort 265 to decrease the incidence of important infectious diseases in these animals. Instead, efforts are 266 more focused on culling of populations (e.g. vampire bats in Latin America) or controlling disease 267 after spill-over into other animal hosts. The continued spillover of rabies virus strains to humans 268 and domestic animals from terrestrial carnivores has led to the development of successful oral 269 rabies vaccination (ORV) programs in Europe and North America. These campaigns often utilize 270 recombinant viral vectors that stimulate immunity to the surface glycoprotein of rabies when 271 ingested orally. When distributed in baits targeted toward certain rabies-carrying species, these 272 vaccines lead to protection from the virus and reduction in local incidence of disease, and even 273 local eradication of some strains of rabies [20, 51]. ORV programs are continually evolving and 274 making use of the best available vaccine technology and disease modeling studies. In this study 275 we assessed whether two attenuated poxviruses might be viable vaccine vectors in a bat species. 276 Through in vivo imaging studies we have demonstrated that attenuated MVA and RCN are able to 277 infect T. brasiliensis via the ON route for a limited time, without causing disease. Our studies 278 demonstrate the tissue tropism and course of infection after exposure of a new animal model, T. 279 brasiliensis, to attenuated orthopoxviruses. We show evidence of limited autologous spread of the 280 viruses after ON exposure, although there is no evidence that the virus spreads outside of GI-281 associated tissues. MVA was cleared faster and resulted in less detectable luminescence compared 282

FIGREF5.text: Further research is required to assess the viral 324 vector in other species, such as vampire bats (Desmodus spp.), for which topically distributed 325 poison protocols are well developed for culling of colonies [15,55]. While culling has been 326 successful in reducing overall numbers of Desmodus at a local level, it has not reduced the 327 incidence of rabies in bat populations and may indeed be counterproductive [17]. Development of 328 topical poxvirus vectored vaccines could potentially lead to effective, applicable, and practical 329 means for reducing disease burden in some free ranging bat populations. 330 331 Acknowledgments 332 We would like to acknowledge the technical assistance of Jennifer Brunner, Elizabeth Falendysz, 333 Nicole Ward, and the other employees at the NWHC that helped with bat care. Additionally, we 334 are grateful to Robin Russell and Katie Richgels for assistance in statistical analysis, Erik 335 Hofmeister for reviewing the manuscript, and David Blehert and Dave Redell for providing their 336 knowledge and expertise. This work was supported by the USGS and the National Institutes of 337 Health, Ruth L. Captions for INFECTIVITY AND IMMUNOGENICITY OF ATTENUATED POXVIRUS VACCINE VECTORS IN THE BRAZILIAN FREE-TAILED BAT (TADARIDA BRASILIENSIS) [Fig 1: Luminescent images for bats given attenuated poxviral vectors, raccoon poxvirus (RCN) or modified vaccinia Ankara (MVA) via intramuscular (IM) (A) or oronasal (ON) routes (B). Images were taken with the IVIS 200 Biophotonic imager and analyzed using the Living Image software. For each vector group, the scale of luminescence is given in photons/second/ cm 2/ steridian (p/s/cm 2 /sr) which has been standardized to compare individuals over time in days post infection (DPI).] [Fig 2. Average luciferase expression per vector by route over time for the four groups of bats given luciferase-expressing constructs. Luminescence is given in photons/second/ cm 2/ steridian (p/s/cm 2 /sr). Luminescence was significantly higher (P=0.028) for those receiving raccoon poxvirus (RCN) than modified vaccinia Ankara (MVA) and also higher (P=0.032) for those administered virus by the intramuscular (IM) route compared to the oronasal (ON) route.] [Fig 3. Average luciferase expression after oronasal (ON) exposure to raccoon poxvirus (RCN) initially and after re-exposure. Luminescence is given in photons/second/ cm 2/ steridian (p/s/cm 2 /sr). No significant difference (P =0.33) was detected in luminescence when compared to initial exposure through 5 days post infection]. [S1 figure. Modified vaccinia Ankara (MVA) gene insertion map showing: 1] DNA flanking segments adjacent to deletion III within the HindIII A fragment of MVA, 2] the Red Fluorescent Protein (RFP) under the control of a p11 promoter, and 3] the firefly luciferase gene (luc) under the control of a strong synthetic early/late (SE/L) vaccinia virus promoter upstream used for construction of MVA-luc.]

FIGREF7.text: Captions for INFECTIVITY AND IMMUNOGENICITY OF ATTENUATED POXVIRUS VACCINE VECTORS IN THE BRAZILIAN FREE-TAILED BAT (TADARIDA BRASILIENSIS) [S2 Figure. Average Proportional Change in Body Weight per Infection Group. The percent change in body weight, compared to day 0 of the study, is shown for each modified vaccinia Ankara (MVA) group [black=intramuscular (IM), blue=oronasal (ON)] and raccoonpox (RCN) group (red=IM, green=ON) until imaging ceased. A repeated measures ANOVA where weight is a function of route and time, plus all interactions (with bats as the repeated measure) revealed no significant effects.] [S3

TABREF0.text: ). Viral 228 infection via IM exposure was cleared within 7 days for MVA and 9 days for RCN, while infection 229 after ON exposure was cleared within 9 days for MVA and 21 days for RCN (final images for RCN 230 given ON not shown). Statistical analysis revealed that luminescence was significantly higher 231 (P=0.028) in bats that received RCN compared to MVA and significantly higher (P=0.032) for those 232 administered virus by the IM route compared to the ON route. In the IM injected groups, 233 significant viral spread to other areas was not evident. In contrast, an initial site of viral 234 replication was evident in the oral cavity after ON exposure, often followed by a secondary site of 235 expression further down the gastrointestinal tract. All luminescence measurements are listed in 236
